cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: After an accident, flares should be used with caution because:
questions.answerA: There may be spilled fuel on the ground that could ignite.
questions.answerB: Other drivers may not see the flares.
questions.answerD: Other drivers may get confused about what is happening.
questions.explanation: After an accident, spilled fuel and improper use of flares can result in a fire.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Rims with a missing lug nut are acceptable if there are at least four other lug nuts on the rim.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring is acceptable if the vehicle is being driven at speeds under 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.answerD: Welded repairs are acceptable for wheels on rear axles.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs can be a dangerous defect. Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are not safe to be used. Wheels or rims with welded repairs are not safe.

questions.question: To receive a hazardous materials endorsement, an applicant will be required to supply:
questions.answerC: A list of countries visited within the last 10 years.
questions.answerD: Their employment history for the previous five years.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you will be required to submit your fingerprints and undergo a TSA background check.

questions.question: When inspecting engine compartment belts during the vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: The belts should be checked for snugness, each with up to three inches of play.
questions.answerB: The water pump belt does not need to be identified.
questions.answerC: The air compressor belt should be removed.
questions.answerD: The applicant must identify which items are not belt-driven, if any.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts. In addition to cracks and frays, you should check the belts for snugness, allowing up to three-quarters of an inch of play at the center of each belt. If any of these items are not belt-driven, you must identify them and ensure that their components are operating properly, are not damaged or leaking, and are mounted securely.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW)?
questions.answerA: The total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a vehicle before cargo
questions.answerD: The maximum weight allowed to be transported by a vehicle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle and its load of cargo.

questions.question: On newer vehicles, how do you put on the parking brake?
questions.answerA: Move a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Push in the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerC: Pull out the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerD: Pull up on the steering column.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The knob is pulled out to set the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: When entering fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn up the volume of the radio.
questions.explanation: If at all possible, it is best to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive through fog, slow down before reaching it.

questions.question: You should not use the parking brake:
questions.answerA: If your vehicle is stopped on a level surface.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle is stopped on a slight incline.
questions.answerC: If your vehicle's brakes are very hot.
questions.answerD: If your vehicle's other braking systems seem to be working adequately.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: If your vehicle is equipped with a cargo lift, you should ensure that:
questions.answerD: The lift is the proper color.
questions.explanation: When checking a cargo lift as part of your vehicle inspection test, you should check for leaking, damaged, or missing parts. The lift must be fully retracted and latched securely.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down extra quickly.
questions.explanation: Air expands as it gets warmer, so the air pressure in your tires could reach dangerously high levels while being used in very hot weather. If this happens, stop and let your tires cool. Do not let air out of the tires, as this could result in the pressure dropping to an unsafe level once the tires cool down.

questions.question: How many points will be added to your driving record for speeding between 11 and 14 mph over posted speed limit?
questions.explanation: In West Virginia's point system, driving between 11 mph and 14 mph faster than the posted speed limit will incur three points on a driver's record. If a driver accrues 12 points or more, their license will be suspended.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: How can you avoid becoming drowsy on a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about three hours of sleep beforehand.
questions.answerC: Do not build exercise into your daily routine.
questions.explanation: Strategies to reduce the risk of fatigue while driving include getting seven to eight hours of sleep beforehand; scheduling trips for the hours during which you are normally awake; planning to take breaks during the trip; and exercising regularly.

questions.question: Bent lock rings:
questions.answerB: Are not a concern in dry weather.
questions.explanation: Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are dangerous and should not be used.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open the door for a better look.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is depressed, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if the green lever on the control panel is pushed down.
questions.explanation: After the brake pedal is pushed down in a vehicle with air brakes, it takes a half-second or more for air to flow through the lines and make the brakes work. This contrasts with hydraulic brakes used in cars and light and medium trucks, which instantly begin working when the pedal is pushed.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road ahead to spot potential hazards well in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards in the event that they become dangerous.

questions.question: During a trip, which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly monitor the instruments, gauges, meters, and mirrors. Check the tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: When completing pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: The inspections should be done the same way each time.
questions.answerB: Different items should be checked each time.
questions.answerC: It is acceptable to check items in a different order each time.
questions.answerD: Not every item needs to be inspected each time.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: If you see lights ahead while driving in fog:
questions.answerA: You can assume the lights are on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.answerD: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: Don't spend too much time looking at a single mirror because:
questions.answerB: Looking at mirrors can make you drowsy.
questions.answerC: It can result in you driving a long distance without looking at the road.
questions.answerD: The mirror may not provide an accurate view of the road.
questions.explanation: Check you mirrors frequently while driving, but check them quickly. Staring at one mirror for too long can cause you to drive a long distance without knowing what is ahead.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerA: You are unlikely to be caught.
questions.answerD: There is no way for authorities to find out.
questions.explanation: A person may not have more than one license. Violation of this law may be punishable by jail time and/or a fine of up to $5,000.

questions.question: When the spring brakes are activated in a vehicle with air brakes, you should never:
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, never push the brake pedal down when the spring brakes are activated. The combined force of the springs and the pressure of the air brakes could damage the brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a person being drowsy?
questions.explanation: Driving drowsy is dangerous and should always be avoided. Warning signs of drowsiness include frequent blinking, your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, frequent yawning, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: When checking the power steering fluid during a vehicle inspection, you will need to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the power steering level is above the refill mark.
questions.explanation: When checking the power steering fluid during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick is located and show that there is an adequate amount of power steering fluid in the engine compartment. The fluid level must be above the refill mark.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, what should you do when the engine is close to idle?
questions.explanation: When stopping a vehicle with a manual transmission, you should push in the clutch when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: If driving a truck that requires a CDL for operation:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You are always required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are only required to wear a seat belt when driving a tank trailer.
questions.explanation: For safety, you must wear your seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: When you must travel down a grade, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerB: After you have already started the grade
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible
questions.answerD: At the bottom of the grade
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, you should shift into a lower gear. This will help get your vehicle to a speed that you can control without having to use your brakes too much.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: It is important to take turns and curves at a safe speed. You should always downshift before entering a curve.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include the following information about distance traveled: trip start and end dates; trip origin and destination points; route(s) of travel; beginning and ending odometer or hubometer readings; total distance traveled; in-jurisdiction distance; and power unit number or vehicle identification number.

questions.question: An applicant will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement if they:
questions.explanation: Your application for a hazardous materials endorsement can be denied, or your existing endorsement canceled, if you do not have legal permanent status in the United States; you renounce U.S. citizenship; you are wanted for, under indictment for, or convicted of certain felonies; you are judged mentally incompetent or are involuntarily committed to a mental institution; or you are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration to pose a security threat.

questions.question: While driving, if it is discovered a vehicle's ABS is not working, the driver should:
questions.answerD: Use their parking brake to stop.
questions.explanation: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are still intact. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: Which type of brakes do most heavy-duty vehicles have?
questions.explanation: For safety, most heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: To prevent fatigue while driving, you should:
questions.explanation: A hot, poorly-ventilated area can make a person sleepy. Opening a window, opening a vent, or using the air conditioning can help keep the cab cool and reduce the risk of fatigue.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Should take over-the-counter remedies to wake them up.
questions.answerC: May make critical decisions too slowly.
questions.answerD: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: If you are fatigued, you will not see or react to hazards as quickly as you would if you were fully energized and awake. You will be impaired in making critical decisions.

questions.question: Without securing a load on a flatbed trailer, cargo may:
questions.answerB: Shift or fall off of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Create a glare, blinding other motorists.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be secured to prevent it from shifting or falling in transit.

questions.question: Fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel use tax returns must be kept by carriers for:
questions.explanation: In general, if you operate a commercial vehicle in interstate commerce, it must be registered under the International Registration Plan (IRP) and International Fuel Tax Agreement (IFTA). These programs collect and distribute vehicle registration fees and fuel taxes based on what jurisdictions you drive in and for how long. Mileage and fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel tax returns must be retained by carriers for four years.

questions.question: A driver can have:
questions.answerA: Two licenses, one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.answerC: A license for each state in which they plan to drive.
questions.answerD: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one license. States share driver data through a computer database to prevent the issuance of duplicate licenses.

questions.question: Air pressure should build up in a single air system within:
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with a single air brake system, after the engine is at operating rpms, the pressure in the air system should generally build from 50 to 90 psi within three minutes.

questions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerC: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you should slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerA: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When entering a foggy area, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop on the side of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Always slow down before entering a foggy area. Use low beam headlights, avoid passing others, and avoid stopping on the side of the roadway. It is safest to completely avoid driving under foggy conditions, if possible.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time, emphasizing different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time so you are less likely to forget something.
questions.answerD: By someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be held:
questions.answerB: With one hand, keeping the other hand free for other tasks.
questions.answerC: With one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: At the base of the wheel.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: In work zones, you should drive at the posted speed limits. Reduce your speed even further when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Point to or touch each item.
questions.answerC: Explain what you are checking and why.
questions.explanation: As a part of earning your CDL, you will have to pass an inspection test and demonstrate that your vehicle is safe for operation. During the vehicle inspection test, you will have to walk around the vehicle and point to or touch each item and explain to the examiner what you are checking and why. You will not have to crawl under the hood or under the vehicle.

questions.question: What is Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The loaded weight of a single vehicle as stated by the manufacturer
questions.answerB: The total weight of the vehicle without a laod
questions.answerC: The total weight of the cargo minus the containers used to transport the load
questions.answerD: The maximum weight allowed to be transported by a vehicle
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: A cargo cover that flaps while you are driving:
questions.answerB: Allows air to keep the cargo cool.
questions.explanation: If cargo is covered, the cover should not flap in the wind in transit. The cover could tear loose, uncovering the cargo while potentially blocking your view or the view of others.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerD: Only use the mirror on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of hazards behind your vehicle when backing, you should frequently check your mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have a helper watch your blind spots whenever possible.

questions.question: If a traffic light has been green for a long time:
questions.answerA: It will probably stay green as you approach.
questions.answerC: It is likely that the light will soon change to yellow.
questions.answerD: It is likely the light will skip yellow and change from green to red.
questions.explanation: If you are approaching a traffic light that has been green for a long time, there is a good chance that it will turn yellow before you reach it. Start slowing down and be ready to stop.

questions.question: When nearing a construction worker who is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When driving through work zones, you should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: In a convex mirror, objects seem ____ than they actually are.
questions.explanation: A convex mirror makes objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: When starting the engine as part of the pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: The maximum speed limit in a residential area, unless otherwise posted, is:
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise posted, the maximum speed limit in residential or business areas in West Virginia is 25 mph. If another maximum speed limit is posted, follow the posted limit.

questions.question: Failing to exit your vehicle properly during an exercise in the basic vehicle control skills test will result in:
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.answerD: An extra point against your score.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The pedal surface has been smoothed out.
questions.answerD: There is something underneath the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: While operating a CMV:
questions.answerA: You are not required to wear a safety belt.
questions.answerB: You are only required to wear a safety belt if your vehicle does not have airbags.
questions.answerC: You are required to wear a safety belt, but only if hauling more than 1,000 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerD: You are always required to wear a safety belt.
questions.explanation: A safety belt is your best defense in the event of a collision. You must always wear a safety belt while operating a CMV.

questions.question: What should be used to check for proper tire inflation?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must use a tire gauge to check for proper tire inflation. You will not receive passing credit if you simply kick the tires.

questions.question: What is the only way to sober up after drinking?
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be increased through tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to wait for the alcohol to be removed from your system.

questions.question: To make driving at night easier, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your interior light turned on.
questions.answerB: Adjust the instrument panel lights as dimly as you can while still being able to read the gauges.
questions.answerC: Not take a nap before driving.
questions.answerD: Use only your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: If the interior of your cab is too bright when you are driving at night, you may have difficulty seeing things outside. Keep the interior light off and adjust your instrument lights to the lowest possible level that still allows you to easily read the gauges.

questions.question: Tires of mismatched sizes:
questions.answerA: Can be used only on a front axle.
questions.answerB: Can be used only on a trailer's axles.
questions.explanation: Tires on the same vehicle should all be equally sized. Ensure your tires are not mismatched when inspecting your vehicle.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerA: Exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerB: Exhaust system parts that are leaking
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts made of aluminum
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerD: Can only be done in dry weather.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be blocked to prevent it from sliding around in transit. The shifting of weight in transit can make steering and handling difficult for the driver.

questions.question: A suspension system:
questions.answerB: Uses pressurized water to support the load.
questions.explanation: Suspension systems receive weight capacity ratings, given by the manufacturers.

questions.question: When parked on the side of a road, you should:
questions.answerD: Stand in the roadway and wave your arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you should turn on your emergency flashers to alert other road users. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: When checking its automatic transmission fluid, the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Should be placed on an incline.
questions.answerB: Should be placed on a decline.
questions.answerD: Should be lifted with a jack.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's engine may need to be running in order for you to check the level of its automatic transmission fluid.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: You should always drive at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: You should always drive slightly below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: You should adjust your speed according to conditions.
questions.answerD: You should drive as fast as possible.
questions.explanation: Operators driving too fast is a major cause of fatal crashes. You must continually adjust your speed to a rate that is safe for road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, you should:
questions.answerA: Open your door for a better look.
questions.explanation: Mirror checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine. It is particularly important to make frequent mirror checks when driving in close quarters.

questions.question: How can a person check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times and hold the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and let go. If the brake makes a squeak, there may be a problem.
questions.answerD: Remove the rear wheel and listen for a noise when the brake pedal is depressed.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable?
questions.answerA: Dual tires that do not come into contact with each other
questions.answerB: Tires of mismatched sizes if used only on short trips
questions.answerC: Retreaded tires on the front of a school bus
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should ensure that dual tires do not come into contact with each other or with other parts of the vehicle. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut or damaged in any way. Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not permitted to be used on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: How many points must be on your record for your driving privileges to be suspended?
questions.explanation: Certain offenses committed while driving will count against a driver in West Virginia's system of suspending driver licenses. If a driver accrues 12 points or more, their license will be suspended.

questions.question: If coolant has to be added to a system without a recovery tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the vehicle running while adding coolant.
questions.answerC: Not use gloves to touch the radiator cap.
questions.answerD: Wait for the engine to cool before adding coolant.
questions.explanation: Before adding coolant to a system without a recovery or overflow tank, you must turn the engine off and wait until it cools. Use gloves or a thick cloth to protect your hands. To release the pressure seal, turn the radiator cap slowly to the first stop.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in work zones?
questions.explanation: Speeding traffic is the main cause of death and injury in work zones. Drive with special caution when traveling near road workers.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include your vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: Over-the-counter medication:
questions.answerA: Poses no safety risks to a driver.
questions.answerB: Is not referenced by any laws regarding driving under the influence.
questions.answerD: Can affect a person’s ability to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Prescription and over-the-counter medications may have side effects that can impair a person's ability to drive safely. It is illegal to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or any other controlled substance, including some over-the-counter medications.

questions.question: To warn drivers behind you that you may be slowing down, you should:
questions.explanation: When you plan to slow down, it is often a good idea to lightly tap your brakes to make the brake lights flash. Doing this will help let drivers behind you know about your intentions.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you can acquire points by:
questions.answerC: Exiting the vehicle one time to check your positioning.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: In cold weather, an alcohol evaporator should be checked and filled:
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed:
questions.explanation: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by one-half or more. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You will likely be able to outdrive a train.
questions.answerB: You should not rely only on warning signals.
questions.answerC: You should roll a window down to listen for an approaching train.
questions.answerD: You should only worry about the track closest to your vehicle.
questions.explanation: You should never rely only on warning signals to alert you to an approaching train. Never try to race a train to a crossing. If there are multiple tracks at a crossing, be sure to check all tracks in both directions before starting to cross.

questions.question: Where can you find the tire load rating?
questions.answerA: On the inside of the driver’s door
questions.answerC: On the side of each tire
questions.explanation: A tire load rating is the maximum safe weight that can be carried by a tire at a specified pressure. This number is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: You should always use at least ____ to secure cargo on a flatbed trailer.
questions.explanation: When transporting cargo on a flatbed trailer, you should use at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Any cargo, no matter how small, should be restrained by a minimum of two tie-downs.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect the driver's head when entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Have air pressure in the braking system even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking system when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build air pressure to allow the brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Maintain air pressure when shut off for periods of less than four hours.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Most drivers are the least alert:
questions.explanation: Fatigue and lack of alertness are major hazards when driving at night. Most people are the least alert at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: Water and compressor oil are usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. Water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the air brake system.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter air tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from air tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks are equipped with drains that allow water and compressor oil to be removed from the system. If allowed to build up, water and compressor oil can damage an air brake system.

questions.question: When preparing to enter traffic, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Wait for a large gap between vehicles.
questions.answerB: Be prepared for your vehicle to accelerate slowly, especially if it is loaded.
questions.answerC: Make sure you can completely cross traffic, if necessary, without interfering with traffic.
questions.answerD: Assume other drivers will make room for your much larger vehicle.
questions.explanation: When crossing or entering traffic, bear in mind the size of your vehicle and the distance it will need to accelerate. Wait for a gap in traffic that is large enough to accommodate your vehicle before you begin to accelerate. Remember that you will need more room to accelerate if your vehicle is heavily loaded. Before crossing a road, be sure that you can get all the way across without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: Once stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the four-way flashers because it is just a test, not an emergency.
questions.answerC: Leave the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Park in front of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: Once you have stopped as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must activate your four-way flashers and shift into neutral or park. You must not block any driveways, intersections, fire hydrants, or signs.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure in your brakes, you should downshift, pump the brakes, and use the parking brake. Seek an escape route, such as an escape ramp, open field, or side street.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Are not controlled by any type of traffic control device.
questions.answerC: Have gates that lower when trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Should never be crossed by a CMV.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that are not controlled by any type of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: Steering that feels heavy is often a sign of:
questions.explanation: If steering begins to feel heavy, it is likely that one of your front tires has failed. If you feel a change to your steering, you should exit the road as quickly as is safely possible and check your tires.

questions.question: When you leave your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the keys in the ignition.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: What do headers do?
questions.answerA: Protect the driver during a crash
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards protect the driver from the forward motion of their cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: What is the minimum permitted size of a placard?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be diamond-shaped and a size of at least 10 ¾ square inches.

questions.question: To stop a vehicle using air brakes:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be lifted.
questions.answerC: The brake knob should be pulled out.
questions.answerD: The brake knob should be pushed in.
questions.explanation: To stop normally in a vehicle with air brakes, press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: An item that is 40 feet long placed on a flatbed trailer should be secured by at least ____ tie-down(s).
questions.explanation: Cargo on a flatbed trailer should be secured by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of the cargo's length. Cargo should be secured by a minimum of two tie-downs, regardless of size.

questions.question: The maximum speed limit in a school zone where children are present, unless otherwise posted, is:
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit in West Virginia school zones where children are present is 15 mph. Always drive with caution when you are near children or other pedestrians.

questions.question: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn quickly in the direction of the skid.
questions.answerC: Countersteer after the vehicle is back on course.
questions.explanation: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, you should first remove your foot from the brake pedal to allow the locked wheels to begin rolling again. Quickly steer in the direction you want to go, then countersteer to prevent your vehicle from skidding in the opposite direction.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but allow the wheels to keep rolling.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up and the vehicle stops.
questions.answerD: Apply the emergency brake until the vehicle starts to slow.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, and then the process is repeated.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the oil pressure should:
questions.answerA: Slowly build up pressure over a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Come up to a normal level within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Start high, then decrease quickly while the engine runs.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: Too little weight on a steering axle can result in:
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a vehicle needs to be balanced appropriately so that it does not interfere with the vehicle's safe handling. For example, if cargo is placed too far to the rear of a vehicle, the front axle will be under-weighted and the front wheels may not have enough traction for the driver to steer safely.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road ahead to spot potential hazards well in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards in the event that they become dangerous.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: When stopped on the side of the road, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important to turn on your four-way emergency flashers to warn other road users.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Which factor does not have an impact on a person’s blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerA: The number of alcoholic drinks consumed
questions.answerB: How quickly the alcoholic drinks were consumed
questions.explanation: The three main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are the amount of alcohol consumed, how quickly the alcohol is consumed, and the person's weight.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The maximum permitted total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The minimum permitted weight of a trailer
questions.answerC: The maximum permitted weight of a trailer and its contents
questions.answerD: The maximum permitted weight of only a tractor
questions.explanation: The Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle plus its load. The Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the maximum combined weight of a vehicle and its cargo that is permitted and specified by the manufacturer.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be securely tied down to keep it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: When turning quickly to avoid an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply your brakes as you steer.
questions.answerB: Give yourself extra clearance by turning more than needed to miss the object.
questions.answerC: Turn just enough to miss the object and avoid turning more.
questions.answerD: Steer and accelerate at the same time.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid an object, turn only as much as is necessary to clear it. Do not apply the brakes while turning.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal:
questions.explanation: When stopping, the brake pedal should be pushed down gradually. Control the pressure so your vehicle comes to a slow, safe stop.

questions.question: When approaching a downgrade, how can you reduce the amount of braking that will be needed?
questions.explanation: Always shift to a lower gear before starting down a hill. Doing this will help your vehicle maintain a safe speed without you needing to use the brakes too much.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: When an engine is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should come on and then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is:
questions.answerC: To wake up before the drive.
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle before a trip is to ensure the safety of yourself and others on the road. Safety inspections before every trip are required by state and federal laws.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: When steering to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use one hand to steer.
questions.answerB: Keep both hands on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors to check other lanes.
questions.answerD: Speed up as you get nearer to the hazard.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid colliding with a hazard in the roadway, you should always keep both hands on the steering wheel. You must have a firm grip on the wheel to be able to turn quickly.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: Fatigue:
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous and increases the risk of a crash. Take precautions before a trip to prevent driving while fatigued.

questions.question: During a written exam:
questions.answerA: Cell phones may be placed on airplane mode.
questions.answerB: Cell phones must be turned off.
questions.answerC: Cell phones may be left on, but must be set in a face down position.
questions.answerD: Cell phones may be left on.
questions.explanation: All electronic devices must be turned off while a written exam is being taken.

questions.question: The service brake system:
questions.answerA: Applies and releases the brakes when you press the brake pedal while driving normally.
questions.answerB: Applies and releases the parking brakes.
questions.answerC: Applies and releases the emergency brake.
questions.answerD: Applies and releases the axle brake.
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system. The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when you use the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers or trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The maximum permitted total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The minimum permitted weight of a trailer
questions.answerC: The maximum permitted weight of a trailer and its contents
questions.answerD: The maximum permitted weight of only a tractor
questions.explanation: The Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle plus its load. The Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the maximum combined weight of a vehicle and its cargo that is permitted and specified by the manufacturer.

questions.question: To best reduce the distractions of a cell phone, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay on a single call for an entire trip.
questions.answerB: Turn the phone off before driving.
questions.answerC: Only us the phone to accept incoming calls.
questions.answerD: Use the phone to text rather than talk.
questions.explanation: If possible, you should avoid all cell phone distractions by turning it off before starting a trip and leaving it off until you reach your destination.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Move over laws require a driver approaching a stopped emergency vehicle to:
questions.answerA: Move into a lane that is not next to the stopped vehicle.
questions.answerC: Move into the far portion of their lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights is stopped on the side of a multilane road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids under the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.answerD: To see if the vehicle is on a decline.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle to conduct an inspection, you should look underneath it to make sure there are no fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks on the ground. Leaks can indicate unsafe defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: If traveling across state lines:
questions.answerA: A driver should have a license for each state that will be visited.
questions.answerB: A driver should have a license for each state where there is a planned stop.
questions.answerC: A driver should have a license for the state where the trip begins and the state where the trip ends.
questions.answerD: A driver should have only one license.
questions.explanation: It is prohibited for any person to have more than one driver license. All states share drivers' information in a computer database to help prevent issuance of licenses to drivers who already have them.

questions.question: If a driver begins to feel fatigued while driving, they should:
questions.answerD: Drive faster to finish the trip more quickly.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the only safe response is to safely leave the road and get some sleep. Using artificial stimulants can be dangerous because they may cause extreme fatigue when they begin to wear off.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.answerD: Hold enough air for more than 1,000 braking cycles.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold enough air for brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: A sign that your vehicle's brakes will need repair is that the:
questions.answerA: Brake pads are not covered in grease.
questions.answerB: Brake pads are not covered in oil.
questions.answerC: The brake pads are worn thin.
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Loading cargo:
questions.answerA: Must be done by the driver.
questions.answerB: Can be done by a second person who is responsible for the safety of the cargo.
questions.answerC: Can be done by a second person, but the driver is responsible for the safety of the cargo.
questions.answerD: Must be done by a person from the shipping company.
questions.explanation: Regardless of who has loaded cargo onto a vehicle, the driver is responsible for the safety of the cargo.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection portion of the skills test, an applicant will be required to:
questions.answerA: Explain to the examiner what should be checked and why.
questions.answerB: Let the examiner check the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Talk to a mechanic to prove their knowledge.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection skills test, you will need to explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: If you are stopped by a law enforcement officer and you do not have your CDL on you, you will:
questions.answerC: Lose your CDL for one year.
questions.explanation: Driving a CMV without your CDL on your person is a serious traffic violation for which you may be cited. You will not be found guilty of this offense if you can provide proof that you had a CDL by the applicable deadline to pay a fine or appear in court.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only be possible if there is still enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can apply the brakes 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should stay at least 100 feet away from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with air brakes, if the low air pressure warning light comes on, it is important for you to stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. There may be a leak in the system. Controlled braking will remain possible only as long as there is enough air left in the tanks.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: What is black ice?
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a crime that would disqualify an applicant from a hazardous materials endorsement?
questions.explanation: There are a number of crimes that will disqualify a person from receiving a hazardous materials endorsement for seven years. Among these offenses are arson, robbery, and crimes of dishonesty, fraud, or misrepresentation. More serious crimes, such as murder, result in a lifetime disqualification.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: When doing an inspection, make sure your brake pads are:
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be held:
questions.answerB: With one hand, keeping the other hand free for other tasks.
questions.answerC: With one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: At the base of the wheel.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: A cargo van carrying a light load is usually:
questions.answerA: The same height as when carrying a heavy load.
questions.answerB: Taller than when carrying a heavy load.
questions.answerC: Shorter than when carrying a heavy load.
questions.answerD: Less stable than when carrying a heavier load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: What is a tire load?
questions.answerA: The minimum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerB: The maximum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerD: The weight of the air within a fully inflated tire
questions.explanation: Tire load is the maximum weight that a tire can safely carry at a specified pressure. This will be stated on the side of a tire.

questions.question: If a person operates in both excepted and non-excepted intrastate commerce, which type of license should the driver select?
questions.explanation: To operate in both excepted intrastate commerce and non-excepted intrastate commerce, you must choose a non-excepted intrastate commerce license.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerD: Only use the mirror on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: To remain aware of hazards behind your vehicle when backing, you should frequently check your mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have a helper watch your blind spots whenever possible.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, what happens if one system is low on pressure?
questions.answerA: The air from the other system will be used to supplement the system with the low pressure.
questions.answerB: The front or rear brakes may not work properly.
questions.answerD: The low system will use an auxiliary system to fill the tank.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The pedal surface has been smoothed out.
questions.answerD: There is something underneath the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a driver who might be a hazard?
questions.answerA: A driver operating a vehicle without first scraping ice off the windshield
questions.answerB: The operator of a rental truck
questions.answerC: The driver of a station wagon with items covering the back windows
questions.answerD: A person operating a pick-up truck
questions.explanation: Drivers with blocked vision may pose hazards to others on the road. Examples of such drivers include those who haven't scraped ice off of their windshields; those driving vehicles loaded with large items blocking the windows; and those who are driving rental trucks without being used to the limited rear visibility of a truck.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: To stop a vehicle using air brakes:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be lifted.
questions.answerC: The brake knob should be pulled out.
questions.answerD: The brake knob should be pushed in.
questions.explanation: To stop normally in a vehicle with air brakes, press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.
