questions.question: When taking the on-road test, you will be evaluated on regular traffic checks. You should not:
questions.answerC: Avoid checking your mirrors near intersections.
questions.explanation: While taking the on-road driving skills test, check for traffic and use your mirrors regularly, especially when encountering intersections. Scan and check for pedestrians in areas where they may be present.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn’t see you.
questions.explanation: It is always safest to assume that other drivers, bicyclists, and pedestrians don't see you. Be prepared for the possibility that they may suddenly move into your path. It may be safe to lightly tap your horn or flash your lights as you pass.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: In bad weather, many drivers:
questions.answerA: Like to drive in front of trucks.
questions.answerB: Like to be on the side of trucks.
questions.answerD: Like to drive without using their lights.
questions.explanation: In bad weather, particularly when visibility is poor, it is common for automobile drivers to follow closely behind trucks. Open up the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you if you are being followed too closely.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: When checking its automatic transmission fluid, the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Should be placed on an incline.
questions.answerB: Should be placed on a decline.
questions.answerD: Should be lifted with a jack.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's engine may need to be running in order for you to check the level of its automatic transmission fluid.

questions.question: When traveling with cargo, you must make sure the cargo is secure:
questions.answerB: Every 150 miles or three hours of driving.
questions.answerC: Only after traveling up a hill.
questions.answerD: Only after coming to a hard stop.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: If a person has a CDL and moves to another state:
questions.answerA: They should continue to use the license until it expires.
questions.answerB: They can keep the license but should get a sticker indicating an address change.
questions.answerC: They must retake all the tests to re-certify for a CDL.
questions.answerD: The must get a new license.
questions.explanation: To drive a commercial motor vehicle in West Virginia, you must apply to transfer your CDL within 30 days of establishing residence in the state.

questions.question: Hydroplaning is like:
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is similar to water skiing: your vehicle's tires glide along the road on a film of water without having traction with the surface of the road.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerD: Can be done with the driver talking to another driver.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading. The process must be properly supervised and done with care.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: The entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts.
questions.answerC: The rear door of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus, the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts, and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: If asked to sight-side back your vehicle into an alley, you should first:
questions.answerA: Pull directly into the alley parking space.
questions.answerB: Turn your vehicle to the right to position yourself directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Pull past the alley and stop perpendicular to the outer boundary.
questions.answerD: Pull past the alley and stop parallel to the outer boundary.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: An active railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: Has a traffic control device installed at the crossing.
questions.answerB: Does not have any traffic control devices installed at the crossing.
questions.answerC: Is characterized by having at least 10 vehicles cross the tracks every hour.
questions.explanation: Active railroad crossings use installed traffic control devices to regulate traffic. These devices can be in the form of flashing red lights, warning bells, and/or gates. The directions of devices controlling railroad crossings must always be followed.

questions.question: School bus stops may be changed by:
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not change the location of a stop without written approval from appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, a bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Place the vehicle in third gear.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus should be put in park. If the transmission does not have a park shift point, the vehicle should instead be placed in neutral.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to display:
questions.answerB: All of the students on the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus. The top portion of the mirror should be positioned to display the top of the bus's rear window. This mirror positioning should allow the driver to see all of the students on the bus, including the heads of the students sitting immediately behind the driver.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: Points are deducted for each pull-up.
questions.answerB: A driver is allowed three pull-ups per maneuver.
questions.answerC: A pull-up will earn points only if the driver gets out of the vehicle before pulling up.
questions.answerD: Only an excessive number of pull-ups will be counted as errors.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, there is no penalty for an initial pull-up; however, an excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: There are blind spots ____ left and right side flat mirrors.
questions.explanation: There are blind spots immediately below and in front of each outside flat mirror. These mirrors have another blind spot directly behind the rear bumper.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: When asked to complete a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: The area to the left of a school bus is considered especially dangerous to students because:
questions.answerA: The sun’s reflection obscures the left side of the bus.
questions.answerB: Passing vehicles are located to the left of the bus.
questions.answerC: It is difficult to see the left side of any bus.
questions.answerD: There is no door on the left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: While all sides of a school bus have danger zones, the left side is particularly hazardous to students due to the presence of passing vehicles.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The pedal surface has been smoothed out.
questions.answerD: There is something underneath the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: Where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.
questions.answerB: Where the front of each front tire touches the ground.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus; the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerD: Usually have a flagger directing traffic.
questions.explanation: Passive railroad crossings are not controlled by any traffic control devices. At such crossings, it is entirely a driver's responsibility to determine when it is safe to cross the tracks.

questions.question: If your bus's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) stops working:
questions.answerA: You will not have any working brakes.
questions.answerB: The brakes will react more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: You will still have normal braking power.
questions.explanation: If its Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, a vehicle will still retain its normal braking power. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help a school bus driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.answerD: Vehicles in front of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: After students unload at a school, the driver:
questions.answerA: May assume students have taken all of their belongings with them.
questions.answerB: Should assume the students have immediately cleared the doorway.
questions.answerC: Should walk through the bus and check for any sleeping or hiding students.
questions.answerD: May turn off the dispatch radio.
questions.explanation: After students have exited a bus at a school, the driver should walk through the bus to check for any remaining students who are hiding or sleeping. Drivers should also look out for items that students may have left behind.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, a bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in first gear.
questions.answerD: Place the vehicle in third gear.
questions.explanation: When stopping to pick up students, a school bus should be put in park. If the transmission does not have a park shift point, the vehicle should instead be placed in neutral.

questions.question: When should you inspect the mirrors on a bus?
questions.answerD: Is not necessary to inspect the mirrors.
questions.explanation: The mirrors of a bus should always be inspected before a trip. Adjust them as necessary before beginning to drive.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: If your vehicle is equipped with a cargo lift, you should ensure that:
questions.answerD: The lift is the proper color.
questions.explanation: When checking a cargo lift as part of your vehicle inspection test, you should check for leaking, damaged, or missing parts. The lift must be fully retracted and latched securely.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: When taking the basic control skills test, drivers are:
questions.answerA: Not permitted to stop and exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerB: Encouraged not to exit the vehicle to look at the vehicle’s position.
questions.answerC: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in reverse.
questions.answerD: Allowed to leave the vehicle, but only if the vehicle is placed in neutral and the parking brake is set.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, you must place the vehicle in neutral and set the parking brake before exiting the vehicle to check its position. You may check the position of the vehicle no more than twice, except during the straight line backing exercise, where you may look no more than once.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: If equipped with flashing lights, how far in advance of a school bus stop should the bus's lights be activated?
questions.explanation: If a school bus is equipped with alternating flashing amber warning lights, they should be activated at least 200 feet before a stop, unless state law requires otherwise.

questions.question: Failing to exit your vehicle properly during an exercise in the basic vehicle control skills test will result in:
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.answerD: An extra point against your score.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Why should a school bus stop a short distance from students who are waiting to board?
questions.answerA: The students will have to walk to the bus, making it easier for the driver to watch their movements.
questions.answerB: The students will usually be waiting on a sidewalk.
questions.answerC: The students may get scared of a school bus coming toward them.
questions.explanation: When being stopped to load students, a school bus should stop at least 10 feet away from the waiting students. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, making it easier for the driver to keep track of their movements.

questions.question: When taking the on-road test, you will be evaluated on regular traffic checks. You should not:
questions.answerC: Avoid checking your mirrors near intersections.
questions.explanation: While taking the on-road driving skills test, check for traffic and use your mirrors regularly, especially when encountering intersections. Scan and check for pedestrians in areas where they may be present.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered a look?
questions.answerA: Walking to the back of a vehicle to check its position
questions.answerB: Using side mirrors to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerC: Looking out of the driver's side window to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerD: A driver glancing over their shoulder to check blind spots
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if there is a need.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students.
questions.answerC: May change, depending on weather conditions.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the proper school district authorities.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not alter the location of a bus stop without written authorization of the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.answerD: Only to be done with students guiding you.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should be done only if there is no other way to move the vehicle.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: During the pre-trip inspection test, you will be:
questions.answerA: Expected to explain your knowledge of the pre-trip process.
questions.answerB: Watching someone else check your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Watching a film on how to inspect a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Changing all the tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: Students should board a school bus:
questions.answerC: In as large a group as possible.
questions.answerD: However they want to. It makes no difference.
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly while in a single-file line and holding the handrails.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of a hazardous material?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for using the hazardous materials regulations to determine the product's identification number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group. They are also responsible for determining the correct packaging, labels, markings, and placards to use.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply any necessary placards.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: Where on a truck should placards be placed?
questions.answerB: On the left and right sides
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: To determine which placard(s) you must use when carrying hazardous materials, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers being used.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are placed on the outside of a vehicle to identify the hazard classes of materials being carried.

questions.question: Regulations require hazardous materials employees to be trained and tested how often?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years. Drivers must learn the risks associated with hazardous materials and be able to properly respond to security threats.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: When accepting a package of hazardous materials, a driver should ensure:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: That all packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: When carrying hazardous materials, it is a good idea to compare the shipping papers to the markings and labels on the packages.

questions.question: Who is responsible for installing placards on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: While shippers of hazardous materials are responsible for providing necessary placards, it is the driver's responsibility to actually place them on the vehicle.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in the trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to a corrosive material must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: Identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guidebook.
questions.explanation: The United States Department of Transportation (DOT)’s Emergency Response Guidebook (ERG) lists all hazardous chemicals and their assigned identification numbers.

questions.question: What shape is a placard indicating hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest route.
questions.explanation: When transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must have a written route plan and follow that plan. Whenever possible, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: To distinguish between hazardous and non-hazardous materials on a shipping paper:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials should be listed at the bottom of the paper.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials should be listed at the top of the paper.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials should be highlighted in the same color as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.answerD: The non-hazardous materials should be marked with an "X."
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be differentiated in one of three ways. They must be listed first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description in a column labeled "HM."

questions.question: If a substance is transported in a reportable quantity, which letters must appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials are being transported in a reportable quantity in one package, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: Materials that are considered hazardous may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials are products that pose risks to health, safety, and property during transportation. Materials that are considered hazardous include explosives; flammable and poisonous gases; and flammable and other hazardous solids.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerA: Should only be used with explosives.
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should only be used by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.answerD: Should be used to reduce insurance rates.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards must be used on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: To know which placards to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers holding the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which hazardous materials placards to use, you must know the hazard class of the materials; the amount of hazardous materials being shipped; and the total weight of all classes of hazardous materials in the vehicle.

questions.question: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table contains:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle that contains hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: No other vehicles should be at the refueling station.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: How must a shipper notify a driver of the risks associated with their cargo?
questions.answerB: By writing a note on a blank piece of paper
questions.answerC: By putting hazard warning labels on packages
questions.answerD: By placing orange dots on packages
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous cargo must alert drivers and others to relevant hazards through proper shipping papers, hazard warning labels on packages, emergency response information, and placards.

questions.question: What can be a clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The shipper is a business you might expect to deal with hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The road is made of gravel.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical suppliers, scientific supply houses, pest control companies, agricultural suppliers, and dealers in explosives, fireworks, or munitions.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The packages should be carried in the cab.
questions.answerC: The packages should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation surrounds packages of radioactive materials and passes through to other nearby packages. To address this, the number of radioactive packages that can be loaded together is limited.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Regulations require hazardous materials employees to be trained and tested how often?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years. Drivers must learn the risks associated with hazardous materials and be able to properly respond to security threats.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Who is responsible for installing placards on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: While shippers of hazardous materials are responsible for providing necessary placards, it is the driver's responsibility to actually place them on the vehicle.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerA: Should only be used with explosives.
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should only be used by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.answerD: Should be used to reduce insurance rates.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards must be used on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers must include:
questions.answerC: The intended use of the materials.
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials.
questions.explanation: Drivers must be aware of the risks associated with materials they are transporting. Hazardous materials shipping papers must include an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: Who must provide emergency response information?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide emergency response information to drivers.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed, except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: The person loading a tank with hazardous materials must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: What must be included in emergency response information?
questions.explanation: Emergency response information for a shipment of hazardous materials must include details about any immediate hazards to health that are associated with the materials.

questions.question: What should be done if the third column of the Hazardous Materials Table contains the word “Forbidden?”
questions.answerA: The indicated substance should not be transported.
questions.answerB: The indicated substance should be transported by air.
questions.answerC: The indicated substance should only be transported at night.
questions.answerD: The indicated substance should be accompanied by a security guard.
questions.explanation: The third column of the Hazardous Materials Table lists items' hazard classes and divisions. Drivers should never transport a material that is marked by the word "Forbidden."

questions.question: If a box contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials packages with containers of liquid inside must have orientation markings with arrows pointing in the direction that should be upright.

questions.question: To determine which placard(s) you must use when carrying hazardous materials, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers being used.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are placed on the outside of a vehicle to identify the hazard classes of materials being carried.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: If a shipping paper has both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.answerC: Written the same way as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When a shipping paper includes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, one acceptable method of identifying the hazardous items is to highlight them in a contrasting color.

questions.question: If required, ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, a vehicle must display four identical placards. A placard should be placed on the front, on the rear, and on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not another name for convex mirrors?
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are also known as "fisheye", "spot", or "bug-eye" mirrors.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread depth of 2/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection of the upper fifth wheel, the glide plate should be:
questions.answerA: Folded under the lower fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Securely mounted to the trailer frame.
questions.answerD: Connected to the emergency air line.
questions.explanation: It is important to always perform a thorough pre-trip inspection before beginning a drive. When inspecting the upper fifth wheel, the glide plate should be securely mounted to the trailer frame.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of the engine.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.answerD: Should be done on surfaces with poor traction.
questions.explanation: Accelerate smoothly and gradually. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Fatigue:
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous and increases the risk of a crash. Take precautions before a trip to prevent driving while fatigued.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue the backing process without changing anything.
questions.answerB: Pull the truck forward, readjust, and start backing again.
questions.answerC: Get out of the truck and move the trailer into the right position.
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel all the way to the left until the trailer straightens out.
questions.explanation: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should pull your truck forward and reposition your vehicle as needed before continuing to back up.

questions.question: When you leave your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: The best way to notice if a trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to become aware that your trailer has begun to skid is to observe it in your mirrors. Checking your trailer in your mirrors will also allow you to spot any skidding at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held by one hand to allow for other tasks, such as eating and drinking.
questions.answerC: Held by one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: Cracked to allow for an improved grip.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper control of your vehicle, the steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands. Your hands should be positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle when driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged because the road ahead is not as important as your current location.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.answerD: Only encouraged when transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. This will allow you to notice hazards as early as possible, giving you time to react to them appropriately.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, the hoses should be checked:
questions.answerB: To ensure that they are still clear.
questions.answerC: To ensure that they are connected to the battery.
questions.answerD: To ensure that they contain the proper amount of play.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: As temperatures begin to rise and ice on road surfaces begin to melt:
questions.answerA: It is especially safe to drive.
questions.answerB: The road will become more slippery.
questions.answerD: It will be easier to identify slippery spots.
questions.explanation: Ice that is wet because it has just begun to melt is much more slippery than ice that is not wet. Use additional caution when driving on melting ice.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights and fog lights to maximize your visibility. Using high beam lights will only make it more difficult for you to see.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: When checking its automatic transmission fluid, the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Should be placed on an incline.
questions.answerB: Should be placed on a decline.
questions.answerD: Should be lifted with a jack.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's engine may need to be running in order for you to check the level of its automatic transmission fluid.

questions.question: Move over laws require a driver approaching a stopped emergency vehicle to:
questions.answerA: Move into a lane that is not next to the stopped vehicle.
questions.answerC: Move into the far portion of their lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights is stopped on the side of a multilane road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of their way.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is try to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact with the driver and do not let yourself be provoked by gestures. Do not try to challenge aggressive drivers by speeding up.

questions.question: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you experience a loss of hydraulic pressure in your brakes, you should downshift, pump the brakes, and use the parking brake. Seek an escape route, such as an escape ramp, open field, or side street.

questions.question: If you don't pull the dolly out from beneath the rear trailer before unlocking the pintle hook:
questions.answerA: The tow bar may cause injury.
questions.explanation: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under the rear trailer. This could cause the dolly tow bar to fly up, possibly causing serious injury.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule to follow when using turn signals?
questions.answerC: Do not use your turn signal if you think others know what you plan to do.
questions.answerD: Cancel your signal after the turn is completed.
questions.explanation: To be certain that others are aware of your intentions, always signal whenever you plan to turn or change lanes. You should signal well in advance of a turn; signal continuously throughout the turn; and make sure to cancel the signal when you are finished turning.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers for oil, coolant, charging circuits, and the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should go out right away.

questions.question: To release a dolly's air brakes before positioning the converter dolly for coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Remove the dolly parking brake control.
questions.explanation: If a converter dolly has air brakes, you can release the brakes by opening the dolly air tank petcock. Releasing the dolly's brakes is the first step you should take when properly positioning the dolly in front of the rear trailer.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: What can happen if one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected?
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.answerD: The driver will be asked to decrease the weight of the load.
questions.explanation: If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line is also referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: When switching gears, what happens if you remain in neutral for too long?
questions.answerB: You may have trouble getting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.answerD: The vehicle will be difficult to stop.
questions.explanation: Remaining in neutral for too long when shifting gears may make it difficult to put the vehicle into the next gear.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: Driving too fast:
questions.answerA: Is a major cause of fatal crashes.
questions.answerB: Can be a good way to get to your destination quickly.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the roadway is dry.
questions.explanation: Driving at excessive speeds is a major cause of fatal crashes. Never drive above the posted maximum speed limit and adjust your speed to fit conditions.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerA: Should only be used with explosives.
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should only be used by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.answerD: Should be used to reduce insurance rates.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards must be used on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: Tread depth in the major grooves on a front tire should be at least:
questions.explanation: Tires need to have at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on other tires.

questions.question: In an engine compartment, loose belts will:
questions.answerA: Not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, causing the engine to overheat.
questions.answerB: Make the engine run more efficiently.
questions.answerC: Make the fan run too much, causing the engine to run too coolly.
questions.explanation: Be sure to check the tightness of the belts in your engine compartment. Loose belts will not turn the water pump and/or fan properly, which can lead the engine overheating.

questions.question: Parking brakes:
questions.answerB: Should be tested, but only after driving a distance.
questions.answerC: Should be tested before a drive.
questions.answerD: Should be tested on a hill.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should always be checked before driving as a part of your pre-trip inspection. If the parking brakes do not hold, the vehicle is faulty and should be fixed.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on the posted signals to indicate when a train is approaching.
questions.answerB: Rely on the movements of other motorists to indicate when a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Not rely on signals to indicate when a train is approaching.
questions.answerD: Look to see if nearby plants are moving from the breeze created by a passing train
questions.explanation: As a precaution, you should always approach a railroad crossing under the assumption that a train is coming. Do not rely only on signals or your hearing to indicate that a train is approaching.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a truck's cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Starting in which year were newly manufactured trailers required to have ABS?
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: When being approached by a vehicle using bright headlights while driving at night, you can avoid being blinded by the headlights by:
questions.answerC: Glancing to the side of road.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded by the lights of an oncoming vehicle at night, you can glance to the right edge of the road until the vehicle has passed.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.answerB: The trailer tends to swing around.
questions.answerC: The cab will swing, but the trailer will stay straight.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection is required:
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require that CMV drivers inspect their vehicles before every trip.

questions.question: Tanks usually have:
questions.explanation: Driving tank vehicles requires special care because they have high centers of gravity. Drivers should be particularly aware of their speeds when operating in turns and curves

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a rule for using turn signals?
questions.answerC: Cancel your signal once your turn or lane change is complete.
questions.answerD: Don’t signal unless another vehicle is close.
questions.explanation: Always signal before a turn or lane change. Begin signaling well in advance of the movement and keep the signal on continuously during the turn. If it is not self-canceling, make sure to turn your signal off after your turn or lane change is complete.

questions.question: If you must make a quick stop while transporting liquids, one safe option is to:
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: If you must make a quick stop to avoid an accident while transporting liquid cargo, it may be a good idea to use the stab braking method. Remember that attempting to steer quickly while braking may cause your vehicle to tip over, especially if it has a high center of gravity.

questions.question: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should not:
questions.answerB: Check the coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answerD: Check the windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: To control a surge, brakes should:
questions.answerB: Not be released too quickly after stopping.
questions.answerC: Be used firmly and then released.
questions.answerD: Be used with the parking brake.
questions.explanation: To help reduce the risk of front-to-back surge when stopping a tank vehicle, keep steady pressure applied to the brakes. Do not release them too quickly after coming to a stop.

questions.question: What can be a clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The shipper is a business you might expect to deal with hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The road is made of gravel.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical suppliers, scientific supply houses, pest control companies, agricultural suppliers, and dealers in explosives, fireworks, or munitions.

questions.question: Multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions are used:
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle run more smoothly.
questions.answerD: To make a vehicle less noisy.
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears. They are usually controlled by a selector knob on the gearshift lever.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: When making a turn, when should you cancel your turn signal?
questions.answerB: In the middle of the turn
questions.explanation: When turning or changing lanes, you should signal early and signal continuously. Cancel your turn signal once the turn or lane change is complete.

questions.question: Before any flammable liquids are loaded or unloaded, the engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.answerB: Swerve as you pass under the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you are not confident that your vehicle will have enough room to safely pass under an overhead object, you should slow down and seek another route, if possible.

questions.question: Emergency air lines are often coded with the color:
questions.explanation: In general, the parts of the service air line are coded blue and the parts of the emergency air line are coded red.

questions.question: When driving through a work zone, you should:
questions.answerD: Steer with one hand to keep the other hand free.
questions.explanation: In work zones, you should observe posted speed limits. Slow down if road or weather conditions are poor, and slow down even further if workers are near the roadway.

questions.question: Which cargo is the most difficult to transport, due to its shifting weight?
questions.explanation: Driving with liquids in a partially-filled tank requires special care because liquids are prone to surge when carried in a tank. Liquid surge causes a vehicle's weight to shift.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, how can you tell if the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working?
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the rear of the trailer will stay on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the trailer will flash three times and then stay on.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights on the trailer will flash and then shut off.
questions.answerD: The blue light near the driver's door will light.
questions.explanation: Trailers equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are equipped on the left rear with a yellow malfunction lamp. If the malfunction lamp stays on after the engine has been started, the ABS is malfunctioning.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerA: At a rate that changes depending on how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerB: At a consistent rate, regardless of how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person drinks coffee.
questions.answerD: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be accelerated through common tricks, such as drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it requires to process the alcohol out of your system.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport Class 3 or Division 2.1 hazardous materials.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible and get it over with.
questions.answerB: First exit the truck and walk the path to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.answerD: Stick your head out the window and look backward.
