questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around the vehicle to check for hazards in your path of travel. Make frequent use of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while backing. Always back up as slowly as possible.

questions.question: Steering that feels heavy is often a sign of:
questions.explanation: If steering begins to feel heavy, it is likely that one of your front tires has failed. If you feel a change to your steering, you should exit the road as quickly as is safely possible and check your tires.

questions.question: What is the minimum permitted size of a placard?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be diamond-shaped and a size of at least 10 ¾ square inches.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Faults in a vehicle's suspension system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: The drive shaft should:
questions.answerA: Be bent toward the passenger side.
questions.answerB: Be bent toward the driver’s side.
questions.answerC: Be bent to one side or the other.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you should check that the drive shaft is not bent or cracked.

questions.question: The standee line:
questions.answerA: Is a line on the floor of a bus that passengers may not cross.
questions.answerB: Is a single-file line of standing passengers.
questions.answerC: Shows the maximum number of people allowed on a bus.
questions.answerD: Shows how tall the passengers on a bus may be.
questions.explanation: While a bus is traveling, passengers may not stand any farther forward than the rear of the driver's seat. To mark this barrier, a bus that is designed to allow passengers to stand must have a two-inch line on the floor (or some other means of showing passengers where they cannot stand). This is known as the standee line.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: A convex mirror is sometimes called a ____ mirror.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles often have curved, convex mirrors, sometimes referred to as "fisheye," "spot," or "bug-eye" mirrors. These mirrors provide a wider view than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids under the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.answerD: To see if the vehicle is on a decline.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle to conduct an inspection, you should look underneath it to make sure there are no fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks on the ground. Leaks can indicate unsafe defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: What can change the height of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, what should you do when the engine is close to idle?
questions.explanation: When stopping a vehicle with a manual transmission, you should push in the clutch when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: A danger of looking at one mirror for too long is:
questions.answerA: You will be distracted by potential hazards.
questions.answerB: You may not see an upcoming hazard in another location.
questions.answerC: The mirrors may shake and move.
questions.answerD: You may notice a dirty spot on the mirror.
questions.explanation: When checking your mirrors, only look at them quickly. If you concentrate on one mirror for too long, you may travel a substantial distance down the road without being aware of what is ahead, missing important information about upcoming hazards.

questions.question: Gasoline:
questions.answerA: Can be brought onto a bus.
questions.answerB: May never brought onto a bus.
questions.answerC: Can be stored in the passenger compartment of a bus during long trips.
questions.answerD: Should be stored in glass containers.
questions.explanation: Bus drivers and passengers should not be permitted to bring common hazardous items, such as gasoline or car batteries, onto a bus.

questions.question: In an emergency, if you must leave the roadway to drive on the shoulder, you should:
questions.answerB: Steer so all wheels are on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stop safely before returning to the road, if possible.
questions.answerD: Stay on the shoulder until the next exit.
questions.explanation: If a hazard requires you to drive onto the shoulder of a road, you should try to keep one set of wheels on the pavement to maintain better control of your vehicle. If possible, stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has come to a complete stop, then pull back onto the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: If a bus is disabled while passengers are still on board:
questions.answerA: Another bus should push the disabled bus to its destination.
questions.answerB: The bus should be towed to its destination.
questions.answerC: The passengers should be asked to push the bus.
questions.answerD: The bus may need be towed to the nearest safe location to discharge the passengers.
questions.explanation: A bus that is disabled while passengers are on board should not be towed or pushed, unless it is absolutely necessary. If needed, the bus should be towed or pushed only as far as the nearest safe location for the passengers to be discharged.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: What are placards?
questions.answerA: Signs placed on a vehicle to identify cargo hazards
questions.answerB: A type of tire used in snowy conditions
questions.explanation: Placards are diamond-shaped warning signs that are placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. Placards are used to identify the specific hazard classes of the cargo being carried.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerC: Make sure the seats are fastened securely.
questions.answerD: Not waste time looking at the handrails and floor lining.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure that everything is safe and in proper working condition. Ensure that all seats are properly fastened to the bus and safe to be used by riders.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, the engine oil pressure should come up to normal:
questions.explanation: After a vehicle's engine is started, the engine's oil pressure should rise to its normal level within seconds. Do not drive a vehicle with oil pressure that is too low.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You will likely be able to outdrive a train.
questions.answerB: You should not rely only on warning signals.
questions.answerC: You should roll a window down to listen for an approaching train.
questions.answerD: You should only worry about the track closest to your vehicle.
questions.explanation: You should never rely only on warning signals to alert you to an approaching train. Never try to race a train to a crossing. If there are multiple tracks at a crossing, be sure to check all tracks in both directions before starting to cross.

questions.question: If an approaching driver is using their high beam headlights, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your high beam lights to remind the driver to switch to their low beams.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerD: Pull to the side of the road until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is coming toward you while using its high beam headlights, glance away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed. This will keep you from being blinded by the lights.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment should be:
questions.answerC: Checked, but only if the driver plans to use the mirrors.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of your mirrors should be checked prior to the start of all trips. Adjust your mirrors as needed.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: You should always drive at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: You should always drive slightly below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: You should adjust your speed according to conditions.
questions.answerD: You should drive as fast as possible.
questions.explanation: Operators driving too fast is a major cause of fatal crashes. You must continually adjust your speed to a rate that is safe for road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: About how many drinks does it take for a 200-pound person to reach a 0.02 percent blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairment begins long before the legal limit is reached. A 200-pound person will reach a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.02 percent after a single drink.

questions.question: When checking the air and electrical lines during a vehicle inspection, all of the following should be true, except:
questions.answerA: The air hoses are making a hissing noise.
questions.answerB: The air hoses and electrical lines are not cut.
questions.answerC: The air lines are not pinched.
questions.answerD: The air lines are not dragging against tractor parts.
questions.explanation: When examining the air and electrical lines as part of your vehicle inspection test, you must listen for leaks. Ensure that the air hoses and electrical lines are not cut, chafed, spliced, or worn. Make sure air and electrical lines are not tangled, pinched, or dragging against tractor parts.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is best to allow more room to open up in front of your vehicle. This will help you avoid the need for sudden stops, which could result in the tailgater rear-ending you, and will make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up may only make things more dangerous by prompting the other driver to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerC: There is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerD: Vehicles are too close to one another.
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver changing lanes or turning too quickly.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Plan trips without allocating extra time for traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Not make gestures to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, begin a trip with realistic expectations of how long the trip will take, allowing extra time for traffic delays. Do not tailgate other vehicles. To avoid upsetting other drivers, do not drive slowly in the left lane and do not gesture at the drivers (even in seemingly minor ways, like shaking your head).

questions.question: When traveling with cargo, you must make sure the cargo is secure:
questions.answerB: Every 150 miles or three hours of driving.
questions.answerC: Only after traveling up a hill.
questions.answerD: Only after coming to a hard stop.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: Tread depth in the major grooves on a front tire should be at least:
questions.explanation: Tires need to have at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on other tires.

questions.question: Emergency exit signs:
questions.answerA: May sometimes be hidden by cargo on the bus.
questions.answerB: Do not need to be displayed because the purpose of an emergency exit is always clear.
questions.answerD: Should be clearly visible and identifiable.
questions.explanation: The emergency exit signs on a bus must always be clearly visible. The emergency door light must work properly, if applicable.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: If a vehicle is found to be over-length during a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Trim the length of the load.
questions.answerC: Ensure flags and lights indicating the oversize load are fastened securely.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals a load to be oversize, the driver must confirm that all required signs, flags, lamps, and reflectors are safely and properly mounted, and that and all required permits are in their possession.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half-force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes until the wheels lock.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Air tanks usually hold enough compressed air:
questions.answerA: For one stop before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerB: For several stops before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerC: For a day’s worth of braking.
questions.answerD: For an unlimited number of stops.
questions.explanation: In an air braking system, the air storage tanks can usually hold enough compressed air for the brakes to be used several times.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerD: Be especially careful because the brakes may fail.
questions.explanation: You should not apply the brake pedal if the spring brakes are activated. The brakes could be damaged if they are subjected to the force of air pressure and the springs at the same time.

questions.question: You should not use the parking brake:
questions.answerA: If your vehicle is stopped on a level surface.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle is stopped on a slight incline.
questions.answerC: If your vehicle's brakes are very hot.
questions.answerD: If your vehicle's other braking systems seem to be working adequately.
questions.explanation: A parking brake should not be used if the vehicle's brakes are very hot from use on a steep downgrade or if the brakes are very wet and temperatures are freezing. Using the parking brake when brakes are hot could cause damage to the brakes, and using the brakes when they are wet in freezing weather may cause the brakes to ice up, rendering the vehicle immobile.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Exit the road and park as soon as safely possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are and park.
questions.answerD: Put on your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Applying the brake pedal causes air pressure to activate an electric switch and:
questions.answerB: Turn on the low pressure warning light.
questions.answerD: Turn off the low pressure warning light.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Maintain full-capacity air pressure in the braking systems even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking systems when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build enough air pressure to brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Do not need time to build air pressure before a trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must allow the air compressor time to build up at least 100 psi of air pressure in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Which part of the truck is the air compressor connected to?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: How is water and compressor oil removed from the bottom of an air storage tank?
questions.answerA: The water and oil are siphoned out of the tank.
questions.answerB: A drain valve is opened to remove the water and oil from the tank.
questions.answerC: The water and oil are removed automatically as the brakes are used.
questions.answerD: A sponge is used to soak up the water and oil.
questions.explanation: Water and compressor oil are removed from air storage tanks through a drain valve. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated tanks must be drained every day to remove this build-up.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Required when transporting both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: With some exceptions, you must have a tank endorsement to transport liquids or gases. This applies to both hazardous and non-hazardous substances.

questions.question: Service brakes should:
questions.answerB: Only be tested by a trained mechanic.
questions.explanation: Before driving, you should always verify that your service brakes are in good working order. Testing the brakes before a trip allows you to locate any problems before you need to brake while on the road.

questions.question: Failing to drain the tanks in an air brake system can result in:
questions.answerA: Water freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do this can cause damage. For example, water that has built up in the system could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only occur if there is enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can brake 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should continue driving, but turn the emergency flashers on to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning light turns on, you should stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. Controlled braking will be possible only as long as enough air remains in the tanks.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: On newer vehicles, how do you put on the parking brake?
questions.answerA: Move a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Push in the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerC: Pull out the yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerD: Pull up on the steering column.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The knob is pulled out to set the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle with dual air brakes, pressure of ____ should be built up in the system before it is driven.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared by both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.answerD: Brakes on only one side of the vehicle will work.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system consists of two separate air brake systems, connected by a single set of brake controls. Each system has its own air tanks.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive with one foot on the accelerator and one foot on the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signals activate, it is essential that you bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half-force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes until the wheels lock.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: What is a wig wag?
questions.answerB: A tube used to move air from the compressor to the tanks
questions.answerC: A noise made by air brakes when used
questions.answerD: A part within the braking unit that allows air to move freely
questions.explanation: A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device in an air brake system. It drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view when the air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter an air tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from an air tank.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual system has two separate air brake systems with a single set of controls.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: Avoid needing to make sudden lane changes by:
questions.answerA: Using your horn to encourage other drivers to move out of your lane.
questions.answerB: Only driving slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Watching the road ahead while driving.
questions.answerD: Pulling off the road and waiting when there is high traffic.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous when driving a combination vehicle. Avoid the need to make a sudden lane change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to open.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: An air supply control lever should be in its "normal" position when you are:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue the backing process without changing anything.
questions.answerB: Pull the truck forward, readjust, and start backing again.
questions.answerC: Get out of the truck and move the trailer into the right position.
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel all the way to the left until the trailer straightens out.
questions.explanation: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should pull your truck forward and reposition your vehicle as needed before continuing to back up.

questions.question: Operating a combination vehicle usually requires ­­­­­____ operating a single vehicle.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.answerD: Exactly the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more skill to drive than single vehicles. Combination vehicles are usually longer and heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollovers.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: What is off-tracking?
questions.answerA: When a vehicle’s front wheels follow a different path than its rear wheels
questions.answerB: When a vehicle's wheels all follow the exact same path
questions.answerC: When a load shifts during a turn
questions.answerD: When a vehicle's wheels run over a curb during a turn
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is known as off-tracking, or "cheating."

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up when nearing a corner.
questions.answerC: Take on-ramps faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when driving a combination vehicle, you should keep the weight of the cargo as low to the ground as possible and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: Look for matching colors when coupling glad hands. Service lines are often:
questions.explanation: When coupling glad hands, make sure to couple together matching glad hands. To help drivers avoid mistakes, color coding is sometimes used. Service lines are often coded with the color blue and emergency lines are often coded with the color red.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and:
questions.answerA: Detach the jaws from around the kingpin.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking lever is in the "emergency" position.
questions.answerD: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: Look for matching colors when coupling glad hands. Service lines are often:
questions.explanation: When coupling glad hands, make sure to couple together matching glad hands. To help drivers avoid mistakes, color coding is sometimes used. Service lines are often coded with the color blue and emergency lines are often coded with the color red.

questions.question: Trailers manufactured after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: ____ are the cause of more than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths.
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: What is a bobtail?
questions.answerC: A tractor that goes faster than the speed limit
questions.answerD: A tractor that goes slower than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as bobtail tractors. Operating a bobtail tractor requires drivers to exercise caution.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up when nearing a corner.
questions.answerC: Take on-ramps faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when driving a combination vehicle, you should keep the weight of the cargo as low to the ground as possible and drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: If colors are being used to distinguish glad hands, which color is used for service lines?
questions.explanation: When trailer air lines are color-coded, the service lines are generally blue and the emergency lines are generally red.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line is also referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: What can the “crack-the-whip” effect do?
questions.explanation: The "crack-the-whip" effect can cause a trailer to turn over during a lane change. To avoid this phenomenon, drivers should make lane changes at slow, safe speeds.
